author: Ian L.

description: I was at the recent grand reopening of this restaurant under a new chef -Nori.  I have to say his take on sushi is amazing.  Everything was delicious!  It is affordable, quick service, and creative take on the food.  Even the Chicken Katsu and tempura calamari were better than anywhere I have eaten for those who dont' eat sushi.  There is definitely something for everyone! Also, try the sweet potatoes that are stacked like Jenga.  yummm!
author: Marichele D.

description: Another overpriced lackluster addition to the rest of the corporate food tourist traps in the Fisherman's Wharf area. Not where this local would go if given the choice.
author: Art L.

description:
Wonderful sushi, wonderful service, wonderful everything.  We had whatever they recommended (Alcatraz, the Basements, Tekka Maki, Tiger and 
Mussels in Sake and to drink, a Sake Bomb).  We cannot rant and rave enough!
author: Faith S.

description: I love this place ever since New ownership  , ! BTW what ever happen to that one gentlemen I think his name is Montenegro  very respectful I only went there because  of him .
author: Sage S.

description: the spicy tuna is super good! definitely must try! egg ramen is very great and not that oily than any other ramen. however the udon soup tastes so different and more intense. i don't really like the udon but my friend like it. the price is so expensive than any other ramen or udon. the service is good.
author: Allentine T.

description: A nice little place to escape the clamor of the tourists in the Fisherman's Wharf area. We were there at happy hour and left very happy, with a nice saki and a Japanese Porter,  along with the meatiest spider rolls I've ever eaten, cooked just a litle soft (less crisp than I prefer).  Good edamame, too - plump, tender, just right salty.
author: Bill V.

description: We had the sushi/sashimi 18 piece sampler with some Sake to wash it down. Service was great, waitress picked a perfect bottle of dry Sake for us. The tuna and salmon were among the freshest we have ever had, my biggest complaint was that there was not more of a variety. The waitress said they focus on the tourist-friendly items, not much of a demand for sea-urchin or eel in this area. The miso soup was perfect, the salad was pretty good. Prices were in line for the area, which is a little high but fits the quality of the food.
author: J G.

description:
Well its FINAL - NEVER COMING BACK!
same with all my co-workers
so sad.. the cashier guy is gone, the menu changed
the food quality changed
which makes sense y i was disappointed last time - the gradual change.
this time: how would you like some soggy sushi?? seriously?!

so if u want the 20% discount for working around there, you're gonna have to ask and they're gonna seem lost becoz it was the other owner who gave it but they'll still honor it for now at least.

go to GRANDEHO KAMEKYO instead its only 2 blocks away and theyre quality never changed.
author: Janet W.

description: bad service, bad food. nothing was right here. rarely do i not eat all sushi. this was so bad i left most of my lunch at the table and got out quick. the worst of the worst.
author: S. G.

description:
We tried to go to a sushi place away from the Wharf but it was closed when we got there so we trekked back to Flying Ninja because we were hungry for sushi and a bit lost on a Sunday night. It worked out fairly well though. The service was pretty "meh" (our food came and we still didn't have our drinks...and it was not busy at all), but the servers were at least pleasant. I also really appreciate the casual environment as we have a two year old and can't do "fancy" with her along. I will break down the food for you:

Miso Soup: Yummy, comfort food. I love Miso Soup and their's was very good.
Chicken/Beef Teriyaki: Not bad. Portion seemed a bit skimpy but I give it a solid 3 stars. 
Spicy Tuna Rolls: Totally decent but comparable to grocery store sushi rolls. Just "pretty good." Nothing "fishy" or off-putting at all.
Sashimi Tuna: Fresh and delicious. Would totally order this again. 

In all, the bill for 4 people came to around $70 and we were full and our sushi craving was satisfied. The location was good for our touristy selves and we took a short walk over to Ghirardelli square and had some wonderful dessert. 

I don't know if I'd eat there again (maybe stop by for a quick sashimi tuna snack?) but it was totally decent.
author: Sarah B.

description: Super delicious! On new years eve we decided to randomly step in for dinner- best idea. Service was very accommodating and friendly. Food was fantastic, I really feel like these people know what they're doing here. Very fresh. I would suggest this place to tourists and locals.
author: Taylor G.

description:
Landed here after four days in the area eating crappy food. I was not in the mood for some lame, tourist laden, heavy Italian-American slop. You know what I'm talking about, lame Italian bread drenched in a mix of margarine and butter and a shake of an Italian herb mix served with a tasteless iceberg lettuce dominated salad, some hot house tomatoes and limp carrot strands next to a bowl of linguine and clam sauce where the clams were probably from China...you get the picture. 
I was aching for something kinda clean, something not laden with animal products. So, I stumbled into this little place and stayed because the servers were all so kind. Met two lovely young kids from Korea - one a waitress, the other a sushi chef - who told me in their broken language a bit more about Korean food and how they missed their families.
I digress...
The food. I had the seaweed salad, a shitake roll and a bowl of udon. Simple. All three dishes met my expectations, fulfilled my cravings and didn't bust my budget. 
Like anything in life, it's as much about the people as anything else...
So, if you find yourself caught in Fisherman's Wharf Tourist hell and can't bear the thought of another weak bowl of cippionio or pasta carbonara, give this a chance -- and engage your server or chef!
author: Annie B.

description:
I actually went there yesterday and it was their grand opening. I was very impressed with their food. It was a lunch meal so the meal was light and very well presented. It is intended to be sushi on wheels. 

We ordered the California rolls which was nicely made and also the Teriyaki Chicken which was also very nice too. You get sticky rice, potato mash and a small green salad with the chicken. I actually really liked it - well done guys!
author: Benjamin L.

description: We went to this place while visiting the Wharf,  The eel sushi was cold, they had a power outage for 15 minutes while we were there, so they could not warm or cook the eel, so they decided to serve it cold, nastiest site I have ever seen.  Service was slow, very cheap and stingy with their portions.  They have no restrooms, they let us wash our hands in the Chefs sink.   Stay away!!
author: Aram T.

description: The menu goes up $5 after Lunch for the same items. Sorry kids if you're going to charge $20 for a roll it better be from heaven. Meh. just OK.
author: Theresa R.
